Award.AwardTitle: Teachers and Engineers Collaborating in STEM Elementary Teacher Preparation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Through the STEM-C Partnerships: MSP program, the Teachers and Engineers Collaborating in STEM Elementary Teacher Preparation (TEC-STEM-ETP) project will design a new model of teacher preparation at Iowa State University which infuses engineering design concepts into the elementary teacher preparation program, as well as emphasizes the knowledge and skills associated with scientific concepts appropriate for elementary school students. This project addresses the critical need for well-prepared elementary teachers to have confidence in and a commitment to engaging their students in experiential learning of essential scientific and engineering concepts in the early grades. The TEC-STEM-ETP is a Partnership among Des Moines Public Schools, the largest school district in the State of Iowa, and Iowa State University, with the School of Education, the College of Engineering, the Engineering and Research Center for Biorenewable Chemicals (CBiRC), and the Center for Excellence in Science, Mathematics, and Engineering Education (CESMEE) working in collaboration.

Designed to make lasting changes to the elementary teacher education program at Iowa State University (ISU), this project will: 1) align ISU elementary teacher education STEM curricula with state and national standards, and incorporate engineering design into the elementary teacher education program; 2) create a program for pre-service and in-service teachers to work in partnership with ISU Master's level engineering graduate students (TEC-STEM Fellows) on a regular weekly basis during the student teaching semester; 3) infuse engineering concepts into the elementary school curriculum in the Des Moines Public Schools; and 4) create a dual-listed undergraduate/graduate course, Engineering and Public Outreach, for engineering students. TEC-STEM-ETP utilizes a novel triad approach, consisting of a pre-service teacher, an in-service teacher and a Master's level engineering student to work collaboratively in a 3rd through 5th grade classroom to teach science well, and implement engineering concepts, mathematics and technology as recommended by the Next Generation Science Standards and required by the Iowa Core Curriculum. The involvement of engineering students in working with elementary pre- and in-service teachers, their students, schools and the community, as well as the Master's level Engineering and Public Outreach course addresses a secondary but important intent of this project to develop communication and public engagement skills of fledgling engineers. The research agenda of TEC-STEM-ETP will determine the effectiveness of this approach to improve elementary teachers' STEM practice and efficacy and to determine reciprocal effects on the engineers. Thus this project stands to make a contribution at the local level, in that there will be an innovative elementary teacher preparation program involving engineering as a legacy. It will also make a national contribution to educational/organizational research as the evidence of the impact of this work, which engages STEM disciplinary faculty members (Environment Physiology, Agriculture and Biological Engineering, Physics, Chemical Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering) working with education faculty and school district personnel, is studied during its development and implementation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project made modifications to the teacher education program at Iowa State University to improve the preparation of elementary teachers to teach both science and engineering. These changes impacted science/engineering content courses, science methods courses, and student teaching. The student teaching experience included professional development for student teachers and their cooperating teachers and support for them in their science/engineering teaching and integration efforts. This project directly impacted more than 1,600 grades 3-5 students, 64 teachers, and 80 student teachers, reaching 23 elementary schools in the Des Moines Public Schools. The students and teachers worked with an engineering graduate student for 16 weeks with the goal of implementing high quality science and engineering instruction as part of the school day. All adult participants received professional development through: 1) workshops led by faculty in science education and engineering; 2) ongoing support from project staff in the classroom; and 3) weekly support for the engineering graduate students for their work with teachers and students. 

Compared to a control group, teachers in this professional development model provided their students with significantly higher quality examples of science phenomena and made more extensive use of classroom discussion. Teachers significantly improved their self-efficacy in teaching engineering and science, and they improved their understanding of what engineering is and what engineers do. We developed a more valid and reliable way to assess teachers? understanding of the scope of engineering work, and we found that teachers improved their understanding over time. We found that teachers conceptualized their science teaching goals in terms of concepts, while their engineering goals were directed toward learning skills and practices, as well as the nature of engineering, rather than engineering concepts. Interestingly, teachers gravitated toward a flowchart process model of the ?Engineering Design Process;? engineers, however, do not conceptualize their work this way. Elementary students in participants? classrooms improved their understanding of engineering, and made positive connections with the engineers in the project.

Evidence exists that causes us to question the extent to which science and engineering can be successfully integrated across the science curriculum in elementary grades. Despite the extensive support provided by the project, including assistance from a STEM expert, only 11% of unit plans submitted to us by project participants successfully integrated engineering with science, and most engineering experiences could be completed by students through trial and error without requiring knowledge of science concepts. We suspect this is due to a number of factors, including inherent difficulties integrating specific concepts across two disciplines with disciplinary integrity, and a lack of curriculum materials that are both practical and well-integrated. 

Finally, science and engineering sense-making experiences in the classroom are very difficult for teachers to do well. In a study of a representative sample of classrooms across the state who did not receive our professional development, sense-making experiences were often cut short or did not occur at all, leading to a focus on activities rather than conceptual development. We have evidence that 40 minutes is a minimum threshold lesson length necessary for teachers to have time to lead quality sense-making experiences. We also found that science is not being taught in 28% of school districts?half of those have replaced their science program with engineering (usually without awareness that the engineering program does not address science concepts), and the other half skip science and engineering entirely.

In summary, this professional development model has demonstrated success in a number of important areas and simultaneously supported student teachers and inservice teachers. Most teachers continue to implement what they learned and report high levels of engagement and interest from students. That said, reform efforts such as NGSS exist in a complex ecosystem. Time for science in elementary grades is insufficient in a majority of schools, and districts are largely unaware that curriculum materials labeled ?STEM? often do not include high quality science. Myriad factors impact how well teachers can teach science to students. The addition of engineering has added complexity to this environment, and while we can prepare teachers to successfully improve students? understanding of engineering, the expectation that this learning will occur through integration is unrealistic for most teachers in existing conditions. Currently, NGSS is more likely to be implemented in upper elementary grades by adding engineering during time for science, which decreases time spent on science. Our work has important implications for federal policy and local schools. Urgent attention is needed to the issue of time allocation in elementary schools, and the availability of high-quality curriculum materials that address science and engineering with disciplinary integrity. In addition, the issue of integration needs further study to determine if science and engineering can be successfully integrated in elementary grades in a way that provides a quality, coherent science education in which engineering enhances rather than detracts from science learning.
